explanation: sem_post — Need its prototype/definition (or macro expansion) to determine whether the call is a runtime-varying function or a compile-time constant/macro (an invariant). OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — The macro/function that yields 'impl' must be inspected to see how it computes the pointer (could expand to invariant code or constant). OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t — To know the type and semantics of the 'id' field (is it a plain constant, or does it refer to a runtime object?). OS_impl_count_sem_table — The table referenced by the macro might be a static/constant table that would make the lookup invariant; inspect its definition. OS_object_token_t — The token type (and any properties of the passed token) could make the lookup deterministic/constant in some contexts; need its definition. OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — The call shown in the static graph likely implements the table lookup; its implementation determines whether the index (and thus impl) varies at runtime. sem_t — The concrete type of impl->id, and any semantics relevant to sem_post behavior (e.g., if id is a compile-time constant or special sentinel). OS_SEM_FAILURE and OS_SUCCESS — Definitions of the return constants to confirm they are simple constants and do not affect the controlling expression analysis. Each of these symbols is required to decide if the controlling expression 'sem_post(&impl->id) < 0' can be considered invariant (a MISRA violation) or is legitimately varying at runtime.
